page.title: 07LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: {LOCAL HISTORY} Myghal Josef was St. Keverne's blacksmith, a man of great force and courage. In 1497 he led a protest against taxation levied by the King for his war against the Scots. Myghal, know as An Gof with Thomas Flamank marched without horses gathering an army of supporters on the way to Blackheath where he engaged the King's army in battle. Following the King's treachery when An Gof was tricked into a parley he was captured and later hung drawn and quartered at Tyburn. An Gof said of himself that he would "Hack a name perpetual and a fame permanent and immortal" He was right. His memorial was unveiled in 1966. Each year there is a ceremony led by Cornish Bards alongside the churchyard where a slate slab commemorates his noble stand.
